TI Twenty-second contribution to the study of African Callichromatini:
   Description of two new species and two new subspecies of Synaptola
   (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae, Cerambycinae, Callichromatini).
FT Vingt-deuxieme contribution a l'etude des Callichromatini africains :
   description de deux especes et deux sous-especes nouvelles de Synaptola
   (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae, Cerambycinae, Callichromatini).
AU Juhel, Pierre (juhelpi@wanadoo.fr) 
SO Cahiers Magellanes-NS
VL 25
PS 1-7
PD Mar 2017
PY 2017
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two years after Synaptola genus revision, the examination of new
   materials allows the description of two new species and two new
   subspecies: Synaptola (str.s.) annamariae n. sp.; S. (str. s.) kamgangi
   n. sp.; S. (str. s.) brevicornis rufipes n. ssp. and S. (Cumaltera)
   fuelleborni camerunensis n. ssp. The male of Synaptola (Metaptola)
   legalli Juhel, 2013 is described.

TI Study and commentary of the Romeo Lumawig collection of the Philippines
   of National Museum of Natural History of Paris (Coleoptera,
   Cerambycidae, Lamiinae).
FT Etude et commentaires de la collection Romeo Lumawig des Philippines du
   Museum National d'Histoire Naturelle de Paris (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae,
   Lamiinae).
AU Chemin, Gerard
   Vives, Eduard
SO Cahiers Magellanes-NS
VL 25
PS 8-28
PD Mar 2017
PY 2017
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB 60 types of Breuning, 1980 of the National Museum of Natural History
   (MNHN), Paris, are catalogued and illustrated. Their original localities
   of the species and the history of the collection are clarified. The new
   synonymies and combinations are introduced: Pseudoplanodes xenoceroides
   (Heller, 1923) = Cacia triangularis Breuning, 1980 nov. syn.; Bumetopia
   fornicata Newman, 1842 = Bumetopia fornicatoides Breuning, 1980 nov.
   syn.; Callimetopus affinis Breuning, 1980 = Faustabryna multifasciata
   Vives, 2014 nov. syn.; Callimetopus lumawigi Breuning, 1980 =
   Callimetopus lazarevi Bargevskis, 2015 nov. syn.; Callimetopus
   mindanaoensis Breuning, 1980 = Callimetopus siargoanus mindanaonis
   Breuning, 1980 nov. syn. and Faustabryna vivesi (Breuning, 1981) nov.
   syn.; Brachyelasma mindanaonis Breuning, 1958 = Tuberculetaxalus
   lumawigi Breuning, 1980 nov. syn.; Mindanaona mindanaonis (Breuning,
   1958) = Mimopterolophia Multituberculata Breuning, 1980 nov. syn.;
   Cereopsius mimospilotus Breuning, 1980 = Cereopsius cabigasi Vives, 2005
   nov. syn.; Acthophora lumawigi Breuning, 1980 = Achtophora chabacana
   Vives, 2013 nov. syn.; Homonoea (Urocalymna) longimana (Westwood, 1842)
   = Homonoea (Urocalymna) longimana albopunctata Breuning, 1980 nov. syn.;
   Rondibilis parvula Heller, 1923 = Driopea (Inermodriopea) excavatipennis
   Breuning, 1980 nov. syn.; Eoporis elegans Pascoe, 1864 = Chydaeopsis
   lumawigi Breuning, 1980 nov. syn.; Glenea albolineata mindanaonis
   Aurivillius, 1926 = Glenea albolineata lumawigi Breuning, 1980 nov.
   syn.; Parazosne leucospilota (Westwood, 1841) = Glenea paralepida
   Breuning, 1980 nov. syn.; Zosne cachita Heller, 1921 = Pseudothyesthes
   flavolineta Breuning, 1980 nov. syn. and Parathyesthes roseolata
   Breuning, 1980 nov. syn.; Pothyne multivittata Breuning, 1980 =
   Phelipara mindorana Vives, 2009 nov. syn.; Phelipara mindanaonis
   (Breuning, 1980) = Phelipara estanleyi Vives, 2009 nov. syn.;
   Pterolophia (s. str.) vitticollis Newman 1842 = Pterolophia
   (Armatopraoneta) lumawigiana Breuning, 1980 nov. syn.; Mispila
   mindanaonis Breuning, 1980 = Mispila albopunctulata Heller, 1923 nov.
   syn.; Zosne Pascoe, 1866 = Parathyestes Breuning, 1980 nov. syn. and
   Pseudothyestes Breuning, 1980 nov. syn.; Tuberculetaxalus Breuning, 1980
   = Mindanaona Ozdikmen, 2008 nov. syn. The new combinations and the new
   names are introduced: Callimetopus affinis Breuning, 1980 = Faustabryna
   affinis (Breuning, 1980) nov. comb.; Cereopsius affinis Breuning, 1980 =
   Blepephaeus affinis (Breuning, 1980) nov. comb.; Niphona (Niphona)
   arrogans ssp. philippinensis Breuning, 1980 = Niphona (Niphona) arrogans
   mindanaona (Breuning, 1980) nov. nom.

DT Article
TI New or interesting Cerambycidae from the Philippines (Part XV)
   (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae, Lamiinae).
AU Vives, Eduard (eduard_vives@hotmail.com) 
SO Cahiers Magellanes-NS
VL 25
PS 47-65
PD Mar 2017
PY 2017
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB This work describes new taxa, proposes a generic and species
   synonymization and presents note on other Lamiini from Philippines. One
   new genus is described: Diplogenes, six new species: Cylindrepomus
   nigerrimus, Diplogenes cylindricus, Paradiallus cabigasi, Paradiallus
   flavolineatus, Cenodocus palawanicus, and Dystasia granulosa. Paraxoes
   Breuning, 1958 is considered to be a junior synonym of Paradiallus
   Breuning, 1950. Paradiallus semperi Breuning and Paradiallus
   ochreostictus Breuning are considered to be a junior synonyms of
   Paradiallus irroratus (Heller). The Apomecynini Mimozeargyra
   flavomaculata Breuning, 1967, are reported as new record to Philippines.
C1 Vives, Eduard; C St Antoni,73, Terrassa, Barcelona, 08221, Spain, Spain.
EM eduard_vives@hotmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1624-1940
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy;
   Taxonomic position; Status; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia

   Dystasia granulosa; Paradiallus cabigasi; Paradiallus flavolineatus

DT Article
TI The Acalolepta species of the group antenor (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae).
AU Vitali, Francesco
SO Cahiers Magellanes-NS
VL 25
PS 66-84
PD Mar 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The species of the group of Acalolepta antenor (Newman, 1842) are
   revised. This revision considers the group as a collective species
   (antenor) with the following subspecies: A. antenor antenor, A. antenor
   magnetica (Pascoe, 1866) rest. status, n. comb., A. antenor auripilis
   (Matsushita, 1935) rest. status, n. comb., A. antenor fasciata
   (Montrouzier, 1855) n. status, n. comb. and A. antenor acanthias
   (Pascoe, 1875) n. status, n. comb. A neotype for Lamia (Monohammus)
   fasciata Montrouzier, 1855 is designed. Cypriola acanthocinoides
   Thomson, 1864 is considered as incertae sedis, since the original
   locality is wrong and the holotype probably false. The following
   synonymies are proposed: A. antenor fasciata = Monochamus captiosus
   Pascoe, 1866 n. syn. = Monochamus uraeus Pascoe, 1866 n. syn. =
   Monochamus anxius Pascoe, 1866 n. syn. = Monochamus argutus Pascoe, 1866
   n. syn. = Dihammus fasciatus aurivarius Gressitt, 1952 n. syn. =
   Acalolepta saintaignani Breuning, 1982 nec Breuning, 1980 n. syn.
C1 Vitali, Francesco; Natl Musee Nat Geschicht, Rue Munster 25, Luxembourg,
   L-2160, Luxembourg, Luxembourg.

SN 1624-1940
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Type material; Combination; Synonymy;
   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Status
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Chrysomeloidea,
   Cerambycidae
OR Acalolepta antenor acanthias - (Pascoe 1875) (Cerambycidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred with status downgrading from Monochamus, p. 82]. 
   Acalolepta antenor auripilis - Matsushita 1935 (Cerambycidae): [Status,
   P. 74]. 
   Acalolepta antenor fasciata - (Montrouzier 1855) (Cerambycidae): [Comb
   nov, Transferred from Lamia (Monohammus), p. 81; Syn nov, Acalolepta
   saintaignani Breuning 1982, p. 81; Syn nov, Dihammus fasciatus
   aurivarius Gressitt 1952, p. 81; Syn nov, Monochamus anxius Pascoe 1866,
   p. 81; Syn nov, Monochamus argutus Pascoe 1866, p. 81; Syn nov,
   Monochamus captiosus Pascoe 1866, p. 81; Syn nov, Monochamus uraeus
   Pascoe 1866, p. 81]. 
   Acalolepta antenor magnetica - (Pascoe 1866) (Cerambycidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Monochamus, p. 81; Stat rev, P. 81]. 
   Acalolepta antenor species group (Cerambycidae): [Revision, P. 66]. 
   Cypriola acanthocinoides - Thomson 1864 (Cerambycidae): [Taxonomic
   position, P. 81]. 
   Lamia (Monohammus) fasciata - Montrouzier 1855 (Cerambycidae): [Neotype
   designated, P. 67; Referred to, Acalolepta, p. 81]. 
   Monochamus acanthias - Pascoe 1875 (Cerambycidae): [Referred with status
   downgrading to, Acalolepta antenor, p. 82]. 
   Monochamus magneticus - Pascoe 1866 (Cerambycidae): [Referred to,
   Acalolepta, p. 81].

TI New and interesting records of the tribe Purpuricenini J. Thomson, 1861
   from China and neighbouring countries (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae).
AU Ambrus, Richard (ambrus@centrum.cz) 
   Tichy, Tomas
SO Cahiers Magellanes-NS
VL 25
PS 85-105
PD Mar 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The following new faunistic records are presented for the tribe
   Purpuricenini Thomson, 1861: Amarysius minax Holzschuh, 1998 from Henan
   (China); Anoplistes halodendri ssp. pirus (Arakawa, 1932) from Sichuan
   and Guangxi (both in China); Dicelosternus corallinus Gahan, 1900 from
   Guangxi (China); Euryphagus miniatus (Fairmaire, 1904) from Laos;
   Parabunothorax rubripennis Pu, 1991 from Yunnan (China) and Thailand;
   Purpuricenus lituratus Ganglbauer, 1887 from Shanxi and Sichuan (China);
   Purpuricenus malaccensis (Lacordaire, 1869) from Guangxi (China);
   Purpuricenus montanus White, 1853 from Pakistan and Himachal Pradesh
   (India); Purpuricenus sideriger sideriger Fairmaire, 1888 from Guangxi
   (China); Purpuricenus temminckii sinensis White, 1853 from Vietnam and
   Quentinius lameerei (Plavilstshikov, 1921) from Yunnan (China).
   Purpuricenus optabilis Holzschuh, 1984, previously know from only one
   female specimen, is reported for the second time more than 30 years
   after its initial discovery in Nepal. Several color habitus photos and
   host plants are presented. Purpuricenus hummeli Pic, 1935 stat. nov. is
   raised to the species level from P. petasifer v. hummeli. In turn,
   Purpuricenus foraminifer Pesarini et Sabbadini, 1997 is synonymised with
   Purpuricenus hummeli Pic, 1935. The species is recorded from new
   localities in Gansu and Sichuan (China).
C1 Ambrus, Richard; Trnkovo Nam 1112-1, Praha, 15200 5, Czech Republic,
   Czech Republic.
EM ambrus@centrum.cz
SC Zoology; Parasitology
SN 1624-1940

TI New contribution to the study of the tribe Aegosomatini in Vietnam with
   the description of a new species of Aegolipton Gressitt, 1940 and a note
   on the identity of the female sex of Aegosoma george Do, 2015
   (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae, Prioninae).
AU Drumont, Alain (alain.drumont@naturalsciences.be) 
   Cuong Do
SO Cahiers Magellanes-NS
VL 25
PS 106-112
PD Mar 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Aegolipton Gressitt, 1940 is described from
   southern-central part of Vietnam (Thua Thien Hue, Quang Nam and Quang
   Ngai provinces) under the name A. tavakiliani n. sp. The new species is
   illustrated and compared with Aegolipton kumei Komiya, 2005 which is, at
   present, its closest species included in this genus. In addition, the
   true female sex of Aegosoma george Do, 2015 is discussed and described
   for the first time.

DT Article
TI A contribution to the knowledge of genus Clinterocera Motschulsky, 1858
   with descriptions of new species (Coleoptera, Scarabaeoidea,
   Cetoniinae).
AU Jakl, Stanislav (Qstanley.jakl@seznam.cz) 
SO Cetoniimania
VL 10
PS 3-25
PD Mar 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Clinterocera hercules new species from south Vietnam, Clinterocera
   sakaii new species from north Vietnam, Clinterocera bancoi new species
   and Clinterocera palawanica new species from Palawan Island
   (Philippines) are described, illustrated and compared with their closest
   congeners. Clinterocera pilifer (Moser, 1921) is synonymised with
   Clinterocera vollenhovii (Westwood, 1874). First male of Clinterocera
   cyprilrusi Legrand & Chew Kea Foo, 2010 is recorded from Sabah (Borneo),
   its brief description is provided. Delimination of Clinterocera species
   groups and their models of distribution is shortly discussed. Taxonomy
   of Clinterocera vollenhovii species group is discussed. New country or
   province records for several Clinterocera species are given.

PT J
AN ZOOR15405026068
DT Article
TI OVERFLOW OF THE LAKE NAM CO DURING ITS HIGH LEVEL PERIOD: INFERENCES
   FROM OXYGEN ISOTOPE OF RADIX SHELLS AND GEOMORPHOLOGICAL EVIDENCES.
AU Chen Feng (chenfeng@itpcas.ac.cn) 
   Feng Jinliang
   Hu Haiping
   Tian Lide
SO Disiji Yanjiu
VL 37
IS 2
PS 271-280
PD Mar 2017
PY 2017
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 5
AB The paleo-lake level and paleohydrological reconstruction is one of the
   most challenging issues in lake investigation. On the Tibetan Plateau,
   many lakes are surrounded by multiple paleo-shorelines and exposed high
   level lake sediments. Nevertheless, the research on the high level lake
   sediments on the Tibetan Plateau is not sufficient. The Lake Nam Co
   (30[degree]30' [approximately] 30[degree]55'N, 90[degree]16'
   [approximately] 91[degree]03'E; 4718m a.s.l.) is located at the
   south-central part of the Tibetan Plateau. It is characterized by the
   semi-arid monsoon climate. Here, the exposed high level lake sediments
   (at 30[degree]52'N and 90[degree]53'E with 2. 96m in thickness) and
   paleo-shoreline from the Lake Nam Co have been investigated. The top of
   the profile is 2. 76m above the modern lake level. We found that the
   fossil shells of Radix are widely distributed in the exposed sediment
   profile from 0. 76m to 1. 87m depth. Most of these fossil shells are
   Gastropoda Radix auricularia (Pulmonata, Lymnaeidae), while a few of the
   broken shells cannot be identified to species level. In this study, we
   refer to the Radix species as ' Radix sp.'. Based on the geochemical
   relationship between Radix sp. shells and its ambient water derived from
   lakes of south central Tibetan Plateau or the specific Lake Nam Co, the
   fossil shells of Radix sp. were used to reconstruct the paleo-electrical
   conductivity (Paleo-EC) and paleohydrochemical features
   ([delta]18OPaleo-water and Sr/CaPaleo-water) of the paleo-lake water
   during the high level period (ca.4. 4 [approximately] 2. 2ka) of the
   Lake Nam Co. The reconstructed Paleo-EC values of the paleo-lake water
   during the high lake level period of Nam Co were between 514 [mu]s/cm
   and 1063 [mu]s/cm. However, the results indicate the reconstructed
   Paleo-EC values of the paleo-lake water depended on the specific
   relationship between the Sr/Ca ratio of the Radix sp. shells and the EC
   of the lake water in Nam Co, rather than relationship built based on
   many various lakes in south central Tibetan Plateau. The reconstructed
   [delta]18OPaleo-water and Sr/CaPaleo-water values of the paleo-lake
   water during the high level period of the Lake Nam Co were between - 12.
   0[per mill] and - 7. 8[per mill], 0. 0002 and 0.0095, respectively.
   Moreover, we confirm that the [delta]18Oshell values of Radix sp.
   significantly depend on hydrological status of lakes. Based on the
   [delta]18Oshell values of fossil Radix sp., we infer that the Lake Nam
   Co existed as a semi-closed lake during its high level period. On the
   other hand, the summit top of watershed between the Lake Nam Co basin
   and its neighboring Lake Ring Co basin is about 4738m a.s.l. The present
   lake water level of both lakes is 4718m a. s.l. and 4648m a. s. l.,
   respectively. Near the study site, we found that the paleo-shoreline is
   ca.30m above the modern lake level, while paleo-water level of the Lake
   Nam Co had exceeded the altitude of watershed. In summary, based on the
   [delta]18Oshell values of fossil Radix sp., the reconstructed
   [delta]18OPaleo-water of the paleo-water body and the geomorphological
   evidence of paleo-shoreline, we infer that the Lake Nam Co may be
   intermittent overflow during its high level period, while the outflow
   water spilled into the neighboring Lake Ring Co basin.
C1 Chen Feng; Shanxi Univ Finance & Econ, Dept Environm Econ, Taiyuan,
   030006, China, China.
EM chenfeng@itpcas.ac.cn
OI Chen, Feng/0000-0001-6210-8146
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Marine
   &Freshwater Biology; Paleontology
SN 1001-7410
BD Skeletal and supporting structures; Shell; Ecology; Habitat; Freshwater
   habitat; Lentic water; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia;
   China; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Quaternary
DE Radix [Shell chemistry / Shell isotope signature / ] [Environmental
   indicators / Palaeoenvironmental reconstruction / ] [Lake / Palaeolake /
   ] [Xizang / Lake Nam Co / ] [Holocene /  / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Pulmonata, Basommatophora, Lymnaeoidea
OR Radix (Lymnaeoidea): [Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15405026068
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR15407036483
DT Article
TI [Descriptions of new African species of Cigaritis Donzel, 1847 and
   synonymy note (Lepidoptera, Lycaenidae) Study on Lycaenidae: note 20.]
FT Descriptions de nouvelles especes africaines de Cigaritis Donzel, 1847
   et note synonymique (Lepidoptera, Lycaenidae) Etude sur les Lycaenidae:
   note no 20.
AU Bouyer, Thierry
SO Entomologia Africana
VL 22
IS 1
PS 2-10
PD Mar 2017
PY 2017
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB Three new Lycaenidae species are described in the genus Cigaritis
   Donzel, 1847. Cigaritis gardineri n. sp. is described from Democratic
   Republic of Congo, Zambia and Tanzania. This species was previously
   confused with Cigaritis montana (Joicey & Talbot, 1924) whose chorology
   and identity are specified. Cigaritis steward n. sp. is described from
   Cameroon. It is a species close to Cigaritis overlaeti (Bouyer, 1998)
   and it was confused in collection with Cigaritis apuleia (Hulstaert,
   1924). Cigaritis piersoni n. sp. is described from Cameroon and is also
   known to Nigeria. It is a species close to the Cigaritis nyassae
   (Butler, 1884) group, but it was often confused with Cigaritis mozambica
   (Bertoloni, 1850) or Cigaritis larseni (Bouyer, 2012). Spindasis
   nairobiensis Sharpe, 1904 is synonymised with Cigarids homeyeri (Dewitz,
   1887), new synonymy.
C1 Bouyer, Thierry; 57 Rue Genot, Chenee, B-4032, Belgium, Belgium.
SC Zoology
SN 1371-7057
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Synonymy; Land zones; Afrotropical
   region; Africa
DE Cigaritis gardineri [Congo-Kinshasa /  / New species] [Tanzania /  / ]
   [Zambia /  / ]. 
   Cigaritis piersoni [Cameroon /  / New species] [Nigeria /  / ]. 
   Cigaritis stewarti [Cameroon /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Papilionoidea, Lycaenidae

   nairobiensis Sharpe 1904, p. 9]. 
   Cigaritis piersoni (Lycaenidae): [Sp nov, Cameroon, P. 8]. 
   Cigaritis stewarti (Lycaenidae): [Sp nov, Cameroon, P. 8].

PT J
AN ZOOR15407036484
DT Article
TI Description of a new species of Dymusia Burmeister from West Africa
   (Coleoptera, Cetoniidae).

TI Review of the Charaxes gallagheri complex resulting in two new species
   and undescribed morphs of Charaxes gallagheri van Son, 1962
   (Lepidoptera, Nymphalidae, Charaxinae).
AU Collins, Steve (collinsabri@gmail.com) 
   Congdon, Colin
   Bampton, Ivan
SO Entomologia Africana
VL 22
IS 1
PS 19-30
PD Mar 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Charaxes gallagheri van Son, 1962 group is revisited. Two new morphs
   of Charaxes gallagheri are described: Charaxes gallagheri f mullini n.
   f. and Charaxes gallagheri f. kirstyae n. f. Two new species are
   described and illustrated with their early stages: Charaxes
   mutinondoensis n. sp. from Eastern Zambia and Charaxes nztuiae n. sp.
   from Central South Tanzania and are also illustrated.
C1 Collins, Steve; ABRI African Butterfly Res Inst, Nairobi, Kenya, Kenya.

DT Article
TI Description of Fornasinius hermes sp. nov. (Coleoptera, Cetoniidae,
   Goliathini).
AU De Palma, Michele (michele.depalma@epfl.ch) 
   Di Gennaro, Cyril
SO Entomologia Africana
VL 22
IS 1
PS 31-38
PD Mar 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Fornasinius hermes n. sp. is described from North-East Uganda; type
   locality: Mt Morungole, Kidepo valley. The new species is reminiscent of
   Fornasinius fornasini Bertoloni, 1852 and Fornasinius aureosparsus
   (Neervoort Van De Poll, 1890), but presents a combination of constant
   characters that distinguish it from both taxa: protibia strongly
   tridentate, mesotibia with external tooth and cephalic apophysis with
   proximal lateral teeth.
C1 De Palma, Michele; Ecole Polytech Fed Lausanne, Sch Life Sci, Lausanne,
   CH-1015, Switzerland, Switzerland.
EM michele.depalma@epfl.ch
SC Zoology

   Africa

   Scarabaeidae
OR Fornasinius hermes (Scarabaeidae): [Sp nov, Uganda, P. 32].

TI Species of Corticeus PILLER & MITTERPACHER, 1783 of the Madagascan
   faunal area - Part I. Four new species from Madagascar (Coleoptera:
   Tenebrionidae, Hypophlaeini).
AU Bremer, Hans J. (hjbremer@live.de) 
   Lillig, Martin
SO Entomologische Zeitschrift
VL 127
IS 1
PS 29-33
PD Mar 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Corticeus PILLER & MITTERPACHER, 1783 of Madagascar, the Mascarene
   Islands and the Comore Islands is revised. In this first part the
   following new species from Madagascar are described and illustrated:
   Corticeus beatulus sp. nov., Corticeus panax sp. nov., Corticeus
   ruthmuellerae sp. nov. and Corticeus steineri sp. nov. In a second,
   forthcoming part annotations on the distribution of the 26 species of
   this region, a determination key and illustrations of the Corticeus
   species will be provided.

   D-49076, Germany, Germany.

DT Article
TI Review of the leafhopper tribe Adelungiini (Hemiptera: Cicadellidae:
   Megophthalminae) from the Indian subcontinent.
AU Viraktamath, C.A. (chandrashekara.viraktamath@gmail.com) 
SO Entomon
VL 42
IS 1
PS 47-58
PD Mar 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two known species of Adelungiini from India (Rajasthan) and Pakistan are
   redescribed and illustrated. These include one new combination, Assiuta
   omani (Kameswara Rao & Ramakrishnan) comb. nov. and the other species
   being Platyproctus maculatus (Pruthi). The leg chaetotaxy and female
   genitalia of these two species are described and illustrated for the
   first time. In addition, male genitalia of the two other species of
   Assiuta Linnavuori namely, A. camena Linnavuori and A. salina Lindberg
   are illustrated. A revised key is given to distinguish the two tribes
   recognised from the region (Agalliini and Adelungiini). (C) 2017
   Association for Advancement of Entomology
C1 Viraktamath, C.A.; Univ Agr Sci, Dept Entomol, Bengaluru, Karnataka,
   560065, India, India.
EM chandrashekara.viraktamath@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0377-9335

   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Adelungiini [Asia / Indian Subcontinent / Taxonomic review] [India /  /
   Key to genera]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs

   Cicadelloidea, Cicadellidae

   Diagnostic characters, P. 50]. 
   Agalliini (Cicadellidae): [Diagnostic characters, P. 58]. 
   Assiuta omani - (Kameswara Rao & Ramakrishnan 1983) (Cicadellidae):
   [First time described, Female genitalia, p. 49; Redescription, P. 48;
   First time figured, Female genitalia, p. 53; Comb nov, Transferred from
   Symphypyga, p. 48].

   figured, Female genitalia, p. 53]. 
   Symphypyga omani - Kameswara Rao & Ramakrishnan 1983 (Cicadellidae):

DT Article
TI Notes on Pachyrhynchini jewel weevils (Coleoptera: Cuculionidae:
   Entiminae) and other insects showing remarkable resemblance in color and
   body pattern characteristics.
AU Yoshitake, Hiraku
SO Gekkan-Mushi
VL 553
PS 22-40
PD Mar 2017
PY 2017
LA Japanese
U1 0
U2 0
AB An outline of Pachyrhynchini weevils and other insects exhibiting
   convergent color and body pattern characteristics was given with many
   concrete examples. Some fundamental problems to be verified were pointed
   out on a widely accepted opinion that other insects mimic Pachyrhynchini
   species armed with a hard exoskeleton. Implications for future studies
   were also provided. In addition, six new species and two new subspecies
   containing representative examples were described.

   Tsukuba, Ibaraki, 3058604, Japan, Japan.

TI A new species of the genus Rhaphidophora from Seram island (Moluccas,
   Indonesia) with notes on the geographic distribution of the subfamily
   Rhaphidophorinae (Orthoptera, Rhaphidphoridae).
AU Di Russo, Claudio
   Rampini, Mauro
SO International Journal of Entomology Research
VL 2
IS 2
PS 55-58
PD Mar 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of Rhaphidophora (R. barociniturricchiae n.sp.) is
   described from a cave of Seram Island (Moluccas, Indonesia). The new
   species shows affinities with R. wasile and R. amboinensis from Halmaera
   and Amboina Islands respectively. The geographic distribution of the
   genus Rhaphidophora and the close genus Stonycophora is discussed in
   relation to the Wallace and Liddeker lines.
C1 Di Russo, Claudio; Univ Rome La Sapienza, Dept Biol & Biotecnol, Viale
   Univ, Rome, Italy, Italy.

DT Article
TI Study on house lizard (Hemidactylus flaviviridis) trematode by scanning
   electron microscopy from different localities of Aizawl district,
   Mizoram, India.
AU Patra, Gautam
   Roy, Leena
   Ghosh, Subhamoy
   Devi, Chirom Nishita
   Borthakur, S.K.
   Lalrinkima, H.
   Lalliankimi, Hmar
   Kathiresan, D.
SO Journal of Entomology and Zoology Studies
VL 5
IS 2 C
PS 189-192
PD Mar 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A survey of helminths in house lizard (Hemidactylus flaviviridis) from
   different parts of Aizawl district of Mizoram was carried out.
   Interestingly one house lizard was found infected with 8 numbers of one
   particular species of trematode among 50 lizards examined. Light
   microscopy (LM) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) revealed that the
   recovered parasite belongs to Postorchigenes sp. This paper presented
   the detail surface morphology of the Postorchigenes sp. of lizard. So
   far, this is the first report of such trematode from this part of India.
C1 Patra, Gautam; Cent Agr Univ, Coll Vet Sci & Anim Husb, Selesih, Aizawl,
   India, India.
SC Parasitology; Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology
BD General morphology; Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites;
   Helminth parasites; Hosts; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia;
   India

   record; prevalence] [Mizoram / Aizawl district / ]. 
   Postorchigenes [General morphology /  / new record; prevalence]
   [Reptilian hosts / Hemidactylus flaviviridis / ] [Mizoram / Aizawl
   district / ]. 
TN Chordates; Invertebrates; Platyhelminths; Reptiles; Vertebrates

DT Article
TI Update list of sponges of Latakia (Syria) - New Record exotic species.
AU Ammar, Izdihar
   Fadel, Sara
SO Journal of Entomology and Zoology Studies
VL 5
IS 2 N
PS 1041-1047
PD Mar 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB This study deals with the diversity of sponge and at the Northern
   Latakia of Syria. The updated detection of sponge biodiversity in the
   Northern Latakia, Syria including previous data was carried out.
   Quantitatively, samples were collected via SCUBA diving at depths
   ranging from 15-30 m in Ibn Hani area near the High Institute of Marine
   Research in 2014. Results revealed 11 species. Chondrosia reniformis,
   Ircinia Sp, Axinella verrucosa, Hippospongia commuis, Crambe crambe,
   Maxilla incrustans, Spongia officinalis, Axinella polypoides, Axinella
   cannabina, Agelas oroides, Agelas linnaei. Most of these species like
   Spongia officinalis and Hippospongia communis were listed as protected
   by the SAP / BIO protocol of the Barcelona Convention. Furthermore, new
   record of exotic species was detected for the first time in the
   Mediterranean and Syrian coast belong to the genus Agelas linnaei from
   Indo-pacific origin exclusively the Thousands Islands of Indonesia.
C1 Ammar, Izdihar; Tishreen Univ, Dept Marine Biol HIMR, Latakia, Syria,
   Syria.
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
BD Documentation; Publications; General morphology; Ecology; Community
   structure; Zoogeography; Dispersal; Means of dispersal; Marine zones;
   Atlantic Ocean; North Atlantic
DE Agelas linnaei [Introduction / Exotic species / New record]
   [Mediterranean Sea / Syria / ]. 
   Demospongiae [Checklists / Updated list / Syria; Latakia] [General
   morphology /  / ] [Species diversity /  / ] [Mediterranean Sea / Syria,
   Latakia / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Sponges
ST Animalia, Porifera, Demospongiae
OR Demospongiae (Porifera). 
   Agelas linnaei (Demospongiae): [New record].

DT Article
TI Morphological Variation in Allocreadium wallagoensis sp nov (Digenea:
   Allocreadiidae) from Wallago attu (Bloch & Schneider, 1801) at Jayakwadi
   Dam of Aurangabad district (MS).
AU Deolalikar, R.V.
SO Journal of Entomology and Zoology Studies
VL 5
IS 2 R
PS 1372-1374
PD Mar 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB In present study, new species of Allocreadium is described from the
   intestine of freshwater cat fish Wallago attu from Jayakwadi Dam of
   Aurangabad district in Maharashtra state of India. Morphologically, in
   this species ovary is smaller than testes, close or even overlapping to
   the anterior border of testis. Cirrus sac is large, well developed,
   lying obliquely anterior to the acetabulum and overlapping left or right
   ceca. Vitellaria are numerous, extending from acetabulum to posterior
   extremity and distributed over both sides around the ceca.
C1 Deolalikar, R.V.; Deogiri Coll, Dept Zool, Aurangabad, Maharashtra,
   India, India.
SC Zoology; Parasitology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Parasites diseases and disorders;
   Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia; India
DE Allocreadium wallagoensis [Piscean hosts / Wallago attu / New parasite
   species] [Maharashtra /  / New species from piscean host]. 
   Wallago attu [Digenean parasites / Allocreadium wallagoensis / New
   parasite species] [Maharashtra /  / New platyhelminth parasite species].
   
TN Chordates; Fish; Invertebrates; Platyhelminths; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Siluriformes, Siluridae, Platyhelminthes, Trematoda, Digenea
OR Wallago attu (Siluridae): [Host]. 
   Allocreadium wallagoensis (Digenea): [Sp nov, Maharashtra, Parasite of
   Wallago attu (Pisces), p. 1373; Parasite].

PM 28812727
DT Article
TI Exceptionally preserved Cambrian loriciferans and the early animal
   invasion of the meiobenthos.
AU Harvey, Thomas H.P. (thph2@le.ac.uk) 
   Butterfield, Nicholas J.
SO Nature Ecology & Evolution
VL 1
IS 3
PS 0022
PD Mar 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 2
U2 12
AB Microscopic animals that live among and between sediment grains
   (meiobenthic metazoans) are key constituents of modern aquatic
   ecosystems, but are effectively absent from the fossil record. We
   describe an assemblage of microscopic fossil loriciferans (Ecdysozoa,
   Loricifera) from the late Cambrian Deadwood Formation of western Canada.
   The fossils share a characteristic head structure and minute adult body
   size (-300 [mu]m) with modern loriciferans, indicating the early
   evolution and subsequent conservation of an obligate, permanently
   meiobenthic lifestyle. The unsuspected fossilization potential of such
   small animals in marine mudstones offers a new search image for the
   earliest ecdysozoans and other animals, although the anatomical
   complexity of loriciferans points to their evolutionary miniaturization
   from a larger-bodied ancestor. The invasion of animals into ecospace
   that was previously monopolized by protists will have contributed
   considerably to the revolutionary geobiological feedbacks of the
   Proterozoic/Phanerozoic transition.
C1 Harvey, Thomas H.P.; Univ Leicester, Dept Geol, Univ Rd, Leicester,
   Leics, LE1 7RH, United Kingdom, United Kingdom.
EM thph2@le.ac.uk
SC Zoology
SN 2397-334X; 2397-334X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Nearctic region; North
   America; Canada; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic
DE Eolorica [Cambrian /  / New genus]. 
   Eolorica deadwoodensis [Saskatchewan /  / new species] [Cambrian /  / ].
   
TN Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Loricifera
OR Eolorica (Loricifera): [Gen nov, Type species Eolorica deadwoodensis, p.
   1, Cambrian; Fossil]. 
   Eolorica deadwoodensis (Loricifera): [Sp nov, Saskatchewan, Cambrian, P.
   1; Fossil].

DT Article
TI Evolution and systematics of Green Bush-crickets (Orthoptera:
   Tettigoniidae: Tettigonia) in the Western Palaearctic: testing
   concordance between molecular, acoustic, and morphological data.
AU Grzywacz, Beata (grzywacz@isez.pan.krakow.pl) 
   Heller, Klaus-Gerhard
   Warchalowska-Sliwa, Elzbieta
   Karamysheva, Tatyana V.
   Chobanov, Dragan P.
SO Organisms Diversity & Evolution
VL 17
IS 1
PS 213-228
PD Mar 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Tettigonia includes 26 species distributed in the Palaearctic
   region. Though the Green Bush-crickets are widespread in Europe and
   common in a variety of habitats throughout the Palaearctic ecozone, the
   genus is still in need of scientific attention due to the presence of a
   multitude of poorly explored taxa. In the present study, we sought to
   clarify the evolutionary relationships of Green Bush-crickets and the
   composition of taxa occurring in the Western Palaearctic. Based on
   populations from 24 disjunct localities, the phylogeny of the group was
   estimated using sequences of the cytochrome oxidase subunit I (COI) and
   the internal transcribed spacers 1 and 2 (ITS1 and ITS2). Morphological
   and acoustic variation documented for the examined populations and taxa
   was interpreted in the context of phylogenetic relationships inferred
   from our genetic analyses. The trees generated in the present study
   supported the existence of three main lineages: "A"-composed of all
   sampled populations of Tettigonia viridissima and the Tettigonia
   vaucheriana complex, "B"-comprising Tettigonia Caudata, Tettigonia
   uvarovi, and the Tettigonia armeniaca complex, and "C"-consisting of
   Tettigonia cantans. The present study provides the first phylogenetic
   foundation for reviewing the systematics of Tettigonia (currently
   classified mostly according to morphological characteristics), proposing
   seven new synonymies.
C1 Grzywacz, Beata; Polish Acad Sci, Inst Syst & Evolut Animals, Slawkowska
   17, Krakow, PL-31016, Poland, Poland.

DT Article
TI Trilobites of the Galgenberg Member (Tannenknock Formation), middle
   Cambrian Stage 5, Franconian Forest, Germany: a paradigmatic lowermost
   middle Cambrian West Gondwanan fauna.
AU Geyer, Gerd (gerd.geyer@uni-wuerzburg.de) 
SO PalZ
VL 91
IS 1
PS 5-70
PD Mar 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Earliest middle Cambrian rocks in the Franconian Forest, formerly known
   as the 'Galgenberg Formation', include a moderately diverse fauna with a
   characteristic West Gondwanan, Atlas-type trilobite assemblage with
   often surprisingly well-preserved specimens. The hitherto inadequately
   characterised and poorly described assemblage includes Kingaspidoides
   franken-waldensis, K. sp. aff. usitata, K. alberti sp. nov., K. meieri
   sp. nov., K.? sp. A, Ornamentaspis cf. crassilimbata, Latikingaspis sp.
   aff. alatus, Enixus sp. aff. juvenis, Acadoparadoxides sp. A,
   Parasolenopleura wurmi sp. nov., Parasolenopleura parabolica sp. nov.
   and Acanthomicmacca franconica Geyer, 2016. In addition to precise
   documentation of the species' morphology and ontogenetic development,
   this study exemplifies allometric developments during the ontogeny of
   ellipsocephaloid and early solenopleurid trilobites, particularly
   Kingaspidoides and Parasolenopleura, and effects of deformation and
   distortion caused by diagenesis and tectonics. It further discusses the
   aspects of the trilobites' ecology and taphonomy, and it characterises
   generic differences within the Kingaspis clade, particularly of
   Kingaspidoides, Latikingaspis and Ornamentaspis.

DT Article
TI Hypoanthraconaia: a new genus of non-marine bivalve molluscs from the
   Early Permian of Far East Russia.
AU Silantiev, Vladimir V. (vladimir.silantiev@kpfu.ru) 
   Urazaeva, Milyausha N.
SO PalZ
VL 91
IS 1
PS 71-84
PD Mar 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Early Permian continental deposits include a large number of localities
   containing anthracosiid-like non-marine bivalves traditionally assigned
   to Anthraconaia Trueman and Weir, 1946, Palaeanodonta Amalitzky, 1895,
   and Palaeomutela Amalitzky, 1892. In most cases, these classifications
   are only tentative due to insufficient preservation in which the shells
   are missing their main characteristics: the ligament and the hinge.
   Non-marine bivalves from the Early Permian Upper Pospelovka Subformation
   of Russky Island (South Primorye, Far East Russia), described here as
   Hypoanthraconaia gen. nov., differ morphologically from the above genera
   by a set of external features including the initial shell, the mode of
   intersection of the growth lines with the dorsal margin, and the details
   of the sculpture. Hypoanthraconaia gen. nov. shows the most external
   similarity with "atypical'' anthracosiid-like morphotypes of
   Anthraconaia that are widespread in the Late Pennsylvanian and Early
   Permian of eastern North America, and the Stephanian and Early Permian
   Lower Rotliegend of northwestern Europe. On this basis, the new genus is
   conventionally assigned to the family Naiaditidae Scarlato and
   Starobogatov, 1979.

   Kazan, 420008, Russia, Russia.

   Vladimir/0000-0003-2858-0708

   species Hypoanthraconaia russkiensis, p. 76, Permian; Fossil].

DT Article
TI Taxonomic review of the 'Bulimes'', terrestrial gastropods from the
   continental Eocene of the Hamada de Meridja (northwestern Sahara,
   Algeria) (Mollusca: Stylommatophora: Strophocheilidae?), with a
   discussion of the genera of the family Vidaliellidae.
AU Hammouda, Sid Ahmed (sid.hammouda@gmail.com) 
   Kadolsky, Dietrich
   Adaci, Mohammed
   Mebrouk, Fateh
   Bensalah, Mustapha
   Mahboubi, M'hammed
   Tabuce, Rodolphe
SO PalZ
VL 91
IS 1
PS 85-112
PD Mar 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 1
U2 7
AB Terrestrial gastropods occur in many North African localities in Eocene
   continental deposits. Here we analyse the faunal assemblage from the
   Hamada de Meridja Formation in southwestern Algeria, dated as Early to
   Middle Eocene on the basis of charophytes. The assemblage consists of
   three closely related species that to date have been classified either
   in the extant Madagascan genus Leucotaenius v. Martens, 1860, or in the
   SW European Eocene genera Romanella Jodot, 1957 and Vicentinia Jodot,
   1957. This is rejected for shell morphological and phylogeographical
   reasons, and a new classification as Maghrebiola gen. nov. is proposed.
   Maghrebiola is tentatively placed in the South American family
   Strophocheilidae, as species from the Early Eocene Itaborai Basin of
   Brazil, currently placed in the genus Eoborus Klappenbach and Olazarri,
   1970 in the family Strophocheilidae, superfamily Acavoidea, have a very
   similar shell habitus. This record possibly extends the known
   geographical range of the Strophocheilidae into the African continent
   during the Eocene. Immigration of this stock into North Africa during
   the Cretaceous via a still existing plate connection is assumed. An
   attribution of Maghrebiola to the African family Achatinidae is unlikely
   for shell morphological reasons despite certain habitus similarities,
   although the Priabonian genera Arabicolaria and Pacaudiella from Oman
   most likely belong into this family, and not to the Vidaliellidae as
   originally proposed. Possible causes for the very low diversity of the
   assemblage are mainly unfavourable living conditions, i.e. a relatively
   dry climate resulting in sparse vegetation and only occasional presence
   of water bodies, which may have had increased salinities, accounting for
   the lack of freshwater mollusks. The absence of any competing large
   gastropods may possibly have facilitated high intraspecific variability
   leading to sympatric occurrence of three closely related species, due to
   the animals occupying a wide range of available ecological niches. As
   the species discussed here have also been attributed to the genera
   Romanella and Vicentinia in the Vidaliellidae, we provide an appendix
   with annotated characterisations of most genera of the Vidaliellidae and
   list the nominal species assigned to them. This family is tentatively
   placed in the South American superfamily Orthalicoidea; its stock would
   have similarly immigrated from South America, but have successfully
   colonized mainly SW Europe, with only one Eocene species (Romanella
   kantarensis (Jodot, 1936)) recognized in Algeria.
C1 Hammouda, Sid Ahmed; Univ Tlemcen, Dept Sci Terre & Univers, BP 119,
   Tlemcen, 13000, Algeria, Algeria.
EM sid.hammouda@gmail.com
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology
SN 0031-0220; 1867-6812

   Combination; Synonymy; Available name; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position;
   Skeletal and supporting structures; Shell; Evolution; Ecology;
   Zoogeography; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Africa; Geological time
   periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Palaeogene; Mesozoic

PT J
AN ZOOR15407036718
DT Article
TI Rediscovery of type material of the bioerosional trace fossil Talpina
   von Hagenow, 1840 and its ichnotaxonomic implications.
AU Wisshak, Max (max.wisshak@senckenberg.de) 
   Neumann, Christian
   Knaust, Dirk
   Reich, Mike
SO PalZ
VL 91
IS 1
PS 127-135
PD Mar 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Friedrich von Hagenow is renowned for his seminal inventory of the
   diverse invertebrate fauna from the lower Maastrichtian chalk (Upper
   Cretaceous) of the Isle of Rugen, Germany. Tragically, his immense
   collection at Stettin (today Szczecin, Poland) was almost completely
   destroyed during World War II, including the type material of hundreds
   of species established by him during the first half of the 19th century.
   Seven belemnite specimens from his collection rediscovered at the Museum
   fur Naturkunde Berlin, as well as 14 belemnites traced at the Museum fur
   Mineralogie und Geologie at the Senckenberg Naturhistorische Sammlungen
   Dresden, include syntypes of four Talpina ichnospecies, labelled T.
   ramosa, T. solitaria, T. foliacea and T. sentiformis. To document this
   material, a new 'digital cylinder seal technique' was applied. The
   rediscovered material allows lectotype designations for T. ramosa and T.
   solitaria (now Trypanites solitarius), whereas T. foliacea and T.
   sentiformis, which where not formally published by von Hagenow, are
   regarded as nomina nuda. As a consequence, the non-topotypical neotypes
   of T. ramosa and T. solitaria, as designated by Ehrhard Voigt in 1972,
   are obsolete.
C1 Wisshak, Max; Marine Res Dept, Sudstrand 40, Wilhelmshaven, D-26382,
   Germany, Germany.
EM max.wisshak@senckenberg.de
RI Wisshak, Max/A-3418-2011
OI Wisshak, Max/0000-0001-7531-3317; Knaust, Dirk/0000-0002-1698-2489;
   Reich, Mike/0000-0003-3837-3497
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 0031-0220; 1867-6812

   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Ecology; Geological time periods; Mesozoic

   material rediscovery; systematics] [Cretaceous /  / ].

   Talpina foliacea (Animalia): [Nomen nudum, P. 134]. 
   Talpina ramosa - von Hagenow 1840 (Animalia): [Lectotype designated, P.
   133]. 
   Talpina sentiformis (Animalia): [Nomen nudum, P. 134]. 
   Talpina solitaria - von Hagenow 1840 (Animalia): [Referred to,
   Trypanites, p. 134]. 
   Trypanites solitarius - (von Hagenow 1840) (Animalia): [Lectotype
   designated, P. 133; Comb nov, Transferred from Talpina, p. 134].

PT J

PM 28615752
DT Article
TI Icriodus marieae, a new icriodontid conodont species from the Middle
   Devonian.
AU Suttner, Thomas J. (thomas.suttner@uni-graz.at) 
   Kido, Erika
   Suttner, Andreas W.W.
SO PalZ
VL 91
IS 1
PS 137-144
PD Mar 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new conodont species, Icriodus marieae, is described from pelagic
   limestone beds of the Carnic Alps (Austria). Specimens are obtained from
   the upper part of the Valentin Formation (Central Carnic Alps) and range
   from the latest Eifelian to middle Givetian. Significantly differing
   from other icriodontid conodonts is that the icriodontan element of the
   new species develops only three denticles on either lateral denticle
   row, which are constricted to the central part of the element. The
   anterior part of the element is free of lateral row denticles and
   consists of two to four denticles, which have a fan-shaped outline in
   lateral view. The anterior part as well as the posterior part
   (consisting of cusp and two to three pre-cusp denticles) is higher than
   the denticles of the central part of the element. Shape analysis
   confirms that the parameters chosen for landmarks (element size relation
   and denticle setting) show little variation between different specimens.
C1 Suttner, Thomas J.; Univ Graz, Inst Earth Sci, Heinrichstr 26, Graz,
   A-8010, Austria, Austria.

PT J
AN ZOOR15405026628
PM 28539687
DT Article
TI Phylogenetic analysis of Monascus and new species from honey, pollen and
   nests of stingless bees.
AU Barbosa, R.N.
   Leong, S.L.
   Vinnere-Pettersson, O.
   Chen, A.J.
   Souza-Motta, C.M.
   Frisvad, J.C.
   Samson, R.A.
   Oliveira, N.T.
   Houbraken, J. (j.houbraken@westerdijkinstitute.nl) 
SO Studies in Mycology
VL 86
PS 29-51
PD Mar 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 3
U2 13
AB The genus Monascus was described by van Tieghem (1884) to accommodate M.
   ruber and M. mucoroides, two species with non-ostiolate ascomata.
   Species delimitation in the genus is still mainly based on phenotypic
   characters, and taxonomic studies that include sequence data are
   limited. The genus is of economic importance. Species are used in
   fermented Asian foods as food colourants (e.g. 'red rice' (ang-kak,
   angka)) and found as spoilage organisms, and recently Monascus was found
   to be essential in the lifecycle of stingless bees. In this study, a
   polyphasic approach was applied combining morphological characters, ITS,
   LSU, [beta]-tubulin, calmodulin and RNA polymerase II second largest
   subunit sequences and extrolite data, to delimit species and to study
   phylogenetic relationships in Monascus. Furthermore, 30 Monascus
   isolates from honey, pollen and nests of stingless bees in Brazil were
   included. Based on this polyphasic approach, the genus Monascus is
   resolved in nine species, including three new species associated with
   stingless bees (M. flavipigmentosus sp. nov., M. mellicola sp. nov., M.
   recifensis sp. nov., M. argentinensis, M. floridanus, M. lunisporas, M.
   pallens, M. purpureus, M. ruber), and split in two new sections (section
   Floridani sect. nov., section Rubri sect. nov.). Phylogenetic analysis
   showed that the xerophile Monascus eremophilus does not belong in
   Monascus and monophyly in Monascus is restored with the transfer of M.
   eremophilus to Penicillium (P. eremophilum comb. nov.). A list of
   accepted and excluded Monascus and Basipetospora species is given,
   together with information on (ex-)types cultures and barcode sequence
   data.
C1 Houbraken, J.; Westerdijk Fungal Biodivers Inst, Uppsalalaan 8, Utrecht,
   NL-3584 CT, Netherlands, Netherlands.
EM j.houbraken@westerdijkinstitute.nl
RI Houbraken, Jos/AAE-7955-2019; Barbosa, Renan/E-5644-2017; DE OLIVEIRA,
   NEIVA TINTI/Q-5314-2019; Frisvad, Jens C/K-2818-2017
OI Barbosa, Renan/0000-0003-2659-9157; DE OLIVEIRA, NEIVA
   TINTI/0000-0002-5568-0360; Frisvad, Jens C/0000-0002-0573-4340; Samson,
   Robert A./0000-0002-2979-3097; Vinnere Pettersson,
   Olga/0000-0002-5597-1870

DT Article
TI Description of Labeo latebra (Cyprinidae) from the Nile River in Sudan.
AU Moritz, Timo (timo.moritz@meeresmuseum.de) 
   Neumann, Dirk
SO Cybium
VL 41
IS 1
PS 25-33
PD Feb 28 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new Labeo species was discovered during surveys conducted on the Nile
   basin in Sudan between 2006 and 2016. It is described herein as Labeo
   latebra sp. nov. It differs from all other Labeo species of the Nile
   basin by having only 12, rarely 13, scales around the caudal peduncle
   (instead of 16 or more), and from all Labeo species occurring in the
   Nile River except L. meroensis by having only 4.5, rarely 5.5, scales
   between lateral line and dorsal fin base (vs. 6.5-7.5 in L. forskalii
   and L. coubie, 6.5-8.5 in L. horie, and 8.5-9.5 in L. niloticus). It can
   be distinguished from L. meroensis by 34-37 scales in lateral line (vs.
   39-41 in L. meroensis). Compared to other species of the genus in the
   Main Nile, the rostral flap is largely fused with the lip and has only a
   small free part. Labeo latebra sp. nov. is a rather compact and
   cylindrical Labeo species with a weakly swollen snout while all other
   Nilotic Labeo species have a clearly elongate appearance and a laterally
   compressed body.
C1 Moritz, Timo; Deutsch Meeresmuseum, Katharinenberg 14-20, Stralsund,
   D-18439, Germany, Germany.
EM timo.moritz@meeresmuseum.de
SC Zoology
SN 0399-0974
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Afrotropical region; Africa
DE Labeo [River Nile /  / Key to species]. 
   Labeo latebra [Sudan /  / New species] [River Nile /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Cypriniformes, Cyprinidae
OR Labeo (Cyprinidae): [Key to species, River Nile, P. 31]. 
   Labeo latebra (Cyprinidae): [Sp nov, Sudan, P. 27].

DT Article
TI Review of Schismatogobius (Gobiidae) from Papua New Guinea to Samoa,
   with description of seven new species.
AU Keith, Philippe (keith@mnhn.fr) 
   Lord, Clara
   Larson, Helen K.
SO Cybium
VL 41
IS 1
PS 45-66
PD Feb 28 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 2
U2 3
AB The species of Schismatogobius from Papua New Guinea to Samoa are
   reviewed and compared to the three known species described from the
   area. Eleven species are recognized including seven new species. These
   are described using genetic and morphomeristic approaches. The species
   differ by a high percentage of divergence in partial COI gene (636 bp)
   and by several characters including the number of pectoral fin rays, the
   pattern of the ventral surface of the head in males and/or females, the
   pectoral fin colour pattern, the jaw length/head length ratio or the jaw
   length of male and/or female, and the fin lengths.
C1 Keith, Philippe; Museum Natl Hist Nat, UMR 7208, CP 026,43 Rue Cuvier,
   Paris, F-75231, France, France.
EM keith@mnhn.fr
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Genetics &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0399-0974

   Australia; Oceanic islands; Pacific Ocean islands

AN ZOOR15305032484
DT Article
TI Biogeographic and taxonomic notes regarding the diversity of fish in the
   Sea of Japan.
AU Tashiro, Fumihito (fumihito.tashiro@gmail.com) 
   Suzuki, Keita W.
   Ueno, Yoichiro
   Funakoshi, Yuki
   Ikeguchi, Shin-ichiro
   Kai, Yoshiaki
SO Taxa
VL 42
PS 22-40
PD Feb 28 2017
PY 2017
LA Japanese
U1 0
U2 0
AB More than 1,300 species of fishes have been reported from the Japanese
   side of the Sea of Japan. However, occurrence records for a great number
   of these species are not documented by voucher specimens, rendering
   estimates of the diversity of fishes from this region unclear as to
   their reliability. Given this situation, ichthyologists at the Maizuru
   Fisheries Research Station of Kyoto University are central to a research
   group aiming to provide a more reliable estimate of the diversity of the
   fish fauna of this region that is based on a reproducible data such as
   voucher specimens. Here we provide some biogeographic (24 species) and
   taxonomic (2 species) notes as a preliminary report towards this goal.
   As a result of new biogeographical findings, 10 species are confirmed
   from this region for the first time, and the distributional ranges of 14
   other species are extended to the east. Most of these 24 species are not
   residents in the Sea of Japan, rather they are migratory species likely
   to have drifted from the southward via the Tsushima Warm Current. An
   unidentified congrid species, Ariosoma sp. and an undescribed
   cynoglossid species, Symphurus sp., were collected off Kyoto Prefecture.
   Exact identification of the former species, and a description and formal
   naming for the latter species, will be the subject of studies conducted
   in the near future.
C1 Tashiro, Fumihito; Kyoto Univ, Field Sci Educ & Res Ctr, Maizuru, Kyoto,
   6250086, Japan, Japan.
EM fumihito.tashiro@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1342-2367
BD Zoogeography; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Pisces [Zoogeography / Biogeography / New record; systematics;
   biodiversity] [North Pacific / Japan, Sea of Japan / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata
OR Pisces (Vertebrata): [New record].

DT Article
TI The genus Syllis Savigny in Lamarck, 1818 (Annelida: Syllidae: Syllinae)
   from Australia (second part): four new species and re-description of
   twelve previously described species.
AU San Martin, Guillermo
   Alvarez-Campos, Patricia
   Hutchings, Pat
SO Zootaxa
VL 4237
IS 2
PS 201-243
PD Feb 28 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Syllis Savigny in Lamarck, 1818, the type genus of Syllidae, is the
   largest and most diverse within the family. This genus presents many
   taxonomic and phylogenetic problems due mainly to the lack of molecular
   data and morphological synapomorphies for many of the species, but also
   to poor or inadequate descriptions. In order to improve the knowledge of
   the genus, we have undertaken a morphological revision of Australian
   species, based on type material and material from the Australian Museum.
   Sixteen species are herein described, of which four are new and twelve
   are redescriptions of already-known species, with six new combinations:
   Syllis boggemanni, n. sp.; S. joaoi, n. sp.; S. karlae, n. sp.; S.
   marceloi, n. sp.; S. albanyensis (Hartmann-Schroder, 1984) n. comb.; S.
   erikae (Hartmann-Schroder, 1981) n. comb.; S. krohnii Ehlers 1864; S.
   lunaris (Imajima, 1966) n. comb.; S. lutea (Hartmann-Schroder, 1960); S.
   macrodentata (Hartmann-Schroder, 1982) n. comb.; S. monilaris Savigny in
   Lamarck, 1818; S. nigropunctata Haswell, 1886; S. pectinans Haswell,
   1920; S. rosea (Langerhans, 1879); S. warrnamboolensis
   (Hartmann-Schroder, 1987) n. comb.; and S. yallingupensis
   (HartmannSchroder, 1982), n. comb.

PM 28264289
DT Article
TI Four new nematode species (Araeolaimida: Comesomatidae, Diplopeltidae)
   from the New Zealand continental slope.
AU Leduc, Daniel (Daniel.Leduc@niwa.co.nz) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 4237
IS 2
PS 244-264
PD Feb 28 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Four new nematode species of the order Araeolaimida are described from
   the continental slope of New Zealand: Sabatieria megadena sp. n.,
   Pararaeolaimus tetradenus sp. n., Southerniella parasimplex sp. n., and
   Diplopeltula cuspidiboja sp. n. The present study provides the first
   record of the genus Pararaeolaimus in the New Zealand Exclusive Economic
   Zone. Pararaeolaimus megaloamphidus Timm, 1961, Diplopeltula mollis
   Bussau, 1993 and Diplopeltula peruensis Bussau, 1993 are considered
   species inquirendae due to the incomplete nature of the original
   descriptions. Southerniella amblynema Bussau, 1993, Southerniella lympha
   Bussau, 1993, and Southerniella nojii Jensen, 1991 are transferred to
   the genus Intasia Tchesunov & Miljutina, 2008 due to the presence of a
   single anterior outsretched ovary. A key to valid Southerniella species
   is provided.
C1 Leduc, Daniel; Natl Inst Water & Atmospher Res NIWA Ltd, Private Bag
   14-901, Wellington, New Zealand, New Zealand.
EM Daniel.Leduc@niwa.co.nz

DT Article
TI Contribution to the cockroach genus Ctenoneura Hanitsch, 1925
   (Blattodea: Corydioidea: Corydiidae) with descriptions of seven new
   species from China.
AU Qiu, Lu
   Che, Yan-Li
   Wang, Zong-Qing (123church@163.com) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 4237
IS 2
PS 265-299
PD Feb 28 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Seven new species of Ctenoneura Hanitsch, 1925, Ctenoneura bawangensis
   sp. nov., Ctenoneura delicata sp. nov., Ctenoneura elongata sp. nov.,
   Ctenoneura heixuanfeng sp. nov., Ctenoneura helicata sp. nov.,
   Ctenoneura papillaris sp. nov. and Ctenoneura qiuae sp. nov. are
   described from Hainan and Yunnan, China. Ctenoneura simulans Bey-Bienko,
   1969 is redescribed and illustrated. Male genitalia of this genus is
   described and illustrated for the first time and is found to lack any
   genital hook. Female Ctenoneura is reported as apterous. Species
   abundance is estimated. Two species groups are suggested and the
   taxonomic status of the genus is discussed. A map and a key to males of
   Chinese Ctenoneura spp. and an updated checklist of the Ctenoneura are
   provided. Habitat photographs of Ctenoneura are shown for the first
   time.

   China, China.

TI The identity of Equatobursa, with proposal of new genus and species
   level synonymies (Hemiptera: Heteroptera: Heterogastridae).
AU Gao, Cuiqing
   Redei, David (cqgao@njfu.edu.cn) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 4237
IS 2
PS 300-306
PD Feb 28 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The identities of the genus Equatobursa Zou, 1985 and its single
   included species, E. nigra Zou, 1985 (Hemiptera: Heteroptera:
   Lygaeoidea: Heterogastridae) are clarified based on the re-examination
   of the type material of the species. The following new subjective
   synonymies are proposed: Sadoletus Distant, 1903 = Equatobursa Zou,
   1985, syn. nov.; Sadoletus izzardi Hidaka, 1959 = Equatobursa nigra Zou,
   1985, syn. nov.

DT Article
TI Contribution to the Uropodina mites of Peru (Acari: Mesostigmata).
AU Kontschan, Jeno (kontschan.jeno@agrar.mta.hu) 
   Friedrich, Stefan
SO Zootaxa
VL 4237
IS 2
PS 359-370
PD Feb 28 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Soil dwelling Uropodina mites were collected from a primary lowland
   rainforest in Amazonian Peru. The species found belong to three
   different families. A new diagnosis and the type genus of
   Tetrasejaspidae fam. nov. are given, and the family is recorded from
   Peru for the first time on the basis of Tetrasejaspis sellnicki
   Hirschmann, 1973. Two rotundabaloghid mites were collected
   (Rotundabaloghia (Circobaloghia) magna Hirschmann, 1992 and
   Rotundabaloghia (Circobaloghia) iquitosensis Hirschmann, 1992), both
   already reported from Peru. A new species (Origmatrachys peruensis sp.
   nov.) from the family Trachyuropodidae was collected in large numbers
   from soil, and is described on the basis of females, males, nymphs and
   larvae. This is the first description of the protonymphs and larvae of
   Origmatrachys. The new species differs from the previously described
   ones in the basis of sculptural pattern of dorsal, ventral, sternal
   shields and the length of the setae in the central part of the dorsal
   shield. A new key to the known adults and deutonymphs of Origmatrachys
   is given.
C1 Kontschan, Jeno; Hungarian Acad Sci, Dept Zool & Anim Ecol, POB 102,
   Budapest, H-1525, Hungary, Hungary.
EM kontschan.jeno@agrar.mta.hu
RI Kontschan, Jeno/G-6807-2012
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type genus; Taxonomy; Key; Land
   zones; Neotropical region; South America
DE Origmatrachys peruensis [Peru /  / New species]. 
   Tetrasejaspidae; Tetrasejaspis sellnicki [Peru /  / New record]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari

   Origmatrachys peruensis (Acari): [Sp nov, Peru, P. 361]. 
   Tetrasejaspidae (Acari): [Fam nov, Of Uropodina, Type genus
   Tetrasejaspis Sellnick 1941, p. 360; New record]. 
   Tetrasejaspis - Sellnick 1941 (Acari): [Designated type genus for new
   family, Tetrasejaspidae, p. 360]. 
   Tetrasejaspis sellnicki (Acari): [New record].

DT Article
TI Etmopterus lailae sp nov., a new lanternshark (Squaliformes:
   Etmopteridae) from the Northwestern Hawaiian Islands.
AU Ebert, David A. (debert@mlml.calstate.edu) 
   Papastamatiou, Yannis P.
   Kajiura, Stephen M.
   Wetherbee, Bradley M.
SO Zootaxa
VL 4237
IS 2
PS 371-382
PD Feb 28 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 1
U2 37
AB A new species of lanternshark, Etmopterus lailae (Squaliformes:
   Etmopteridae), is described from the Northwestern Hawaiian Islands, in
   the central North Pacific Ocean. The new species resembles other members
   of the "Etmopterus lucifer" clade in having linear rows of dermal
   denticles, and most closely resembles E. lucifer from Japan. The new
   species occurs along insular slopes around seamounts at depths between
   314-384 m. It can be distinguished from other members of the E. lucifer
   clade by a combination of characteristics, including a longer anterior
   flank marking branch, arrangement of dermal denticles on the ventral
   snout surface and body, flank and caudal markings, and meristic counts
   including number of spiral valve turns, and precaudal vertebrate. A key
   to species of the Etmopterus lucifer-clade is included.
C1 Ebert, David A.; Moss Landing Marine Labs, Pacific Shark Res Ctr, 8272
   Moss Landing Rd, Moss Landing, CA, 95039, USA, USA.
EM debert@mlml.calstate.edu
OI kajiura, stephen/0000-0003-3009-8419
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Marine zones;
   Pacific Ocean
DE Etmopterus [North Pacific / Hawaii / Distribution]. 
   Etmopterus lailae [North Pacific / Hawaii / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Chondrichthyes, Elasmobranchii,
   Squaliformes, Squalidae
OR Etmopterus (Squalidae). 
   Etmopterus lailae (Squalidae): [Sp nov, Hawaii (marine), P. 372]. 
   Etmopterus lucifer-* clade (Squalidae): [Key to species, P. 379].

TI A review of Smicronyx Schoenherr (Coleoptera, Curculionidae) of Israel,
   with description of two new species.
AU Haran, Julien (julien.haran@cirad.fr) 
   Schuette, Andre
   Friedman, Ariel-Leib-Leonid
SO Zootaxa
VL 4237
IS 1
PS 17-40
PD Feb 27 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The species of the genus Smicronyx sensu lato (Curculionidae,
   Curculioninae) occurring in Israel are reviewed. A total of seven
   species is recorded. Two species are newly recorded for the country (S.
   pauperculus Wollaston, 1864 and S. albosquamosus Wollaston, 1854), and
   two new species are described: S. jordanicus Haran and S. longitarsis
   Haran. A key to species, diagnosis of the new species, new biological
   and distribution data together with line illustrations of some
   characters, including male genitalia, and colour photographs of the
   habitus are provided.

DT Article
TI Two new eriophyoid mite species (Trombidiformes: Eriophyoidea) from the
   cocoa tree, and a note on Shevtchenkella biseta (Nalepa).
AU Rodrigues, Daniela F.S.
   Navia, Denise (denise.navia@embrapa.br) 
   Oliveira, Anibal R.
   Ferragut, Francisco
   Flechtmann, Carlos H.W.
SO Zootaxa
VL 4237
IS 1
PS 112-130
PD Feb 27 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Two new eriophyoid mite species are described from the cocoa tree,
   Theobroma cacao L. (Malvaceae) - the Diptilomiopidae Davisella trevisani
   n. sp. Rodrigues, Navia & Oliveira, from Brazil; and the Eriophyidae
   Tetra theobromae n. sp. Rodrigues, Navia & Oliveira, from Costa Rica.
   The new Davisella species presents an enlarged subcylindrical tubercle
   bearing pedipalp genual seta d, a novel structure for eriophyoid mites;
   its functional morphology was discussed. The new Tetra species is the
   third in this genus described from plants of the Malvaceae. A closer
   look at Shevtchenkella biseta (Nalepa), described from the Malvaceae
   Hibiscus rosa-sinensis L., showed its taxonomic assignment to the
   Phytoptidae, Sierraphytoptinae and raised a hypothesis on its synonymy.
C1 Navia, Denise; CNPq Brazil Researcher, Embrapa Recursos Geneticos
   Biotecnologia, Brasilia, DF, BR-770900, Brazil, Brazil.
EM denise.navia@embrapa.br

   diseases and disorders; Hosts; Land zones; Neotropical region; Central
   America; South America

PM 28264307
DT Article
TI New Pycnomerus Erichson (Coleoptera: Zopheridae: Pycnomerini) from
   Rimatara, French Polynesia.
AU Porch, Nick (nporch@deakin.edu.au) 
   Smith, Tessa R.
SO Zootaxa
VL 4237
IS 1
PS 154-166
PD Feb 27 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB We describe two species of Pycnomerus, P. rimatara and P. prebblei,
   using subfossil material, from the island of Rimatara in the Austral
   Archipelago of French Polynesia. We consider it likely that these
   species are globally extinct, a result of the combination of a range of
   factors including: their probable single island endemic status, the lack
   of intact indigenous forest on Rimatara, their occurrence in the
   subfossil record only in samples older than 200-300 years before the
   present, and lack of historical collections. The potential extinction of
   these species reflects the long history of human transformation of
   Polynesian lowland forest habitats, especially the use of fire to
   transform landscapes, and parallels extensive and well-known extinctions
   in birds and land snails.
C1 Porch, Nick; Deakin Univ, Ctr Integrated Ecol, Geelong, Vic, 3216,
   Australia, Australia.
EM nporch@deakin.edu.au
OI Smith, Tessa/0000-0002-8811-6221
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oceanic islands;
   Pacific Ocean islands; French Polynesia
DE Pycnomerus prebblei; Pycnomerus rimatara [Tubuai Islands /  / New
   species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Tenebrionoidea,
   Colydiidae

   Pycnomerus rimatara (Colydiidae): [Sp nov, Tubuai Islands, P. 157].

DT Article
TI A new species of Pseudocrenilabrus (Perciformes: Cichlidae) from Lake
   Mweru in the Upper Congo River System.
AU Katongo, Cyprian (ckatongo@unza.zm) 
   Seehausen, Ole
   Snoeks, Jos
SO Zootaxa
VL 4237
IS 1
PS 181-190
PD Feb 27 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB Pseudocrenilabrus pyrrhocaudalis sp. nov. is described from Lake Mweru
   in the upper Congo River drainage, on the border of the Democratic
   Republic of Congo and Zambia. This species, which appears to be endemic
   to the lake, lives in sympatry with P. philander. Pseudocrenilabrus
   pyrrhocaudalis sp. nov. is distinguished from P. philander in nuptial
   males by the presence of an orange colour on the ventral part of the
   body and the proximal parts of the anal and caudal fins, a broad band of
   bright white on the distal edge of anal and caudal fins, a uniform grey
   head and dorsum, and a subtruncate caudal fin. In addition, P.
   pyrrhocaudalis has a shorter snout, a narrower head, a smaller
   interorbital distance, a smaller pre-anal distance, a more slender
   caudal peduncle and fewer scales around the caudal peduncle in both
   sexes.
C1 Katongo, Cyprian; Univ Zambia, Dept Biol Sci, POB 32379, Lusaka, Zambia,
   Zambia.
EM ckatongo@unza.zm
RI Seehausen, Ole/C-8272-2011; Seehausen, Ole/Y-2420-2019
OI Seehausen, Ole/0000-0001-6598-1434

SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Afrotropical region;
   Africa
DE Pseudocrenilabrus pyrrhocaudalis [Zambia /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Perciformes, Cichlidae

DT Article
TI A new species of freshwater crab of the genus Himalayapotamon Pretzmann,
   1966 (Decapoda, Brachyura: Potamidae: Potaminae) from Uttarakhand,
   northern India.
AU Pati, S.K. (sameer_pati@yahoo.co.in) 
   Singh, S.
SO Zootaxa
VL 4237
IS 1
PS 191-200
PD Feb 27 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of potamid freshwater crab, Himalayapotamon garhwalense n.
   sp., is described from a stream near Khanda in Pauri Garhwal district of
   Uttarakhand, India. The new species is differentiated from all congeners
   by a suite of carapace and gonopod features, including the short, stout
   and conical G1 terminal joint with gradually tapered distal portion.
   Himalayapotamon Pretzmann, 1966, is now represented by 11 species
   including H. garhwalense n. sp. An identification key to the species in
   the genus is provided.
C1 Pati, S.K.; Zool Survey India, Western Reg Ctr, Sect 29, Pune,
   Maharashtra, 411044, India, India.
EM sameer_pati@yahoo.co.in

DT Article
TI Biodiversity and phylogeny of Ammotheidae (Arthropoda: Pycnogonida).
AU Sabroux, Romain
   Corbari, Laure
   Krapp, Franz
   Bonillo, Celine
   Le Prieur, Stepahnie
   Hassanin, Alexandre (romain.sabroux@mnhn.fr) 
SO European Journal of Taxonomy
VL 286
PS 1-33
PD Feb 24 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB The family Ammotheidae is the most diversified group of the class
   Pycnogonida, with 297 species described in 20 genera. Its monophyly and
   intergeneric relationships have been highly debated in previous studies.
   Here, we investigated the phylogeny of Ammotheidae using specimens from
   poorly studied areas. We sequenced the mitochondrial gene encoding the
   first subunit of cytochrome c oxidase (CO1) from 104 specimens. The
   complete nuclear 18S rRNA gene was sequenced from a selection of 80 taxa
   to provide further phylogenetic signal. The base composition in CO1
   shows a higher heterogeneity in Ammotheidae than in other families,
   which may explain their apparent polyphyly in the CO1 tree. Although
   deeper nodes of the tree receive no statistical support, Ammotheidae was
   found to be monophyletic and divided into two clades, here defined as
   distinct subfamilies: Achelinae comprises the genera Achelia Hodge,
   1864, Ammothella Verrill, 1900, Nymphopsis Haswell, 1884 and Tanystylum
   Miers, 1879; and Ammotheinae includes the genera Ammothea Leach, 1814,
   Acheliana Arnaud, 1971, Cilunculus Loman, 1908, Sericosura Fry &
   Hedgpeth, 1969 and also Teratonotum gen. nov., including so far only the
   type species Ammothella stauromata Child, 1982. The species Cilunculus
   gracilis Nakamura & Child, 1991 is reassigned to Ammothella, forming the
   binomen Ammothella gracilis (Nakamura & Child, 1991) comb. nov.
   Additional taxonomic re-arrangements are suggested for the genera
   Achelia, Acheliana, Ammothella and Cilunculus.
C1 Hassanin, Alexandre; Sorbonne Univ, Museum Natl Hist Nat, 55 Rue
   Buffon,CP 51, Paris, F-75005, France, France.
EM romain.sabroux@mnhn.fr
RI Sabroux, Romain/AAF-1020-2019; Sabroux, Romain/AAF-1009-2019; Hassanin,
   Alexandre/AAP-8634-2020
OI Sabroux, Romain/0000-0002-1029-3017; Hassanin,
   Alexandre/0000-0002-4905-8540; Corbari, Laure/0000-0002-3323-6162
SC Zoology; Genetics &Heredity
SN 2118-9773
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Combination;
   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Genetics; Evolution
DE Ammotheidae [Molecular genetics / COI & 18S rRNA gene sequences /
   systematics] [Phylogeny /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Pycnogonida
OR Ammotheidae (Pycnogonida). 
   Ammothella gracilis - (Nakamura & Child 1991) (Pycnogonida):
   [Combination revalidated, Transferred back from Cilunculus, p. 16]. 
   Ammothella stauromata - Child 1982 (Pycnogonida): [Designated type
   species for new genus, Teratonotum, p. 16]. 
   Cilunculus gracilis - Nakamura & Child 1991 (Pycnogonida): [Referred to,
   Ammothella, p. 16]. 
   Teratonotum (Pycnogonida): [Gen nov, Of subfamily Ammotheinae, Type
   species Ammothella stauromata Child 1982, p. 16]. 
   Teratonotum stauromata - (Child 1982) (Pycnogonida): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Ammothella, p. 16].

DT Article
TI Cryptic diversity in the Azorean beetle genus Tarphius Erichson, 1845
   (Coleoptera: Zopheridae): An integrative taxonomic approach with
   description of four new species.
AU Borges, Paulo A.V. (pborges@uac.pt) 
   Amorim, Isabel R.
   Terzopoulou, Sofia
   Rigal, Francois
   Emerson, Brent C.
   Serrano, Artur R.M.
SO Zootaxa
VL 4236
IS 3
PS 401-449
PD Feb 24 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Recent findings based on molecular data support the occurrence in the
   Azores of several independently evolving lineages of the beetle genus
   Tarphius Erichson, 1845 (Coleoptera: Zopheridae Solier, 1834) and higher
   species richness masked by cryptic diversity, needing formal taxonomic
   description. All Tarphius from the Azores are revised using an
   integrative taxonomic approach, using evidence from morphology,
   morphometrics and molecular data to delimit species. Our results reveal
   that Azorean Tarphius comprise at least five phyletic lineages, two of
   which share a similar morphology, despite being divergent at the
   molecular level. A total of four new species are described grouped into
   two complexes: i) two new species in the "complex tornvalli" with the
   new taxa Tarphius relictus sp. nov. (Terceira) and Tarphius furtadoi sp.
   nov. (Sao Jorge, Faial and Pico) and; ii) two new species in the
   "complex azoricus-wollastoni-depressus" with the new taxa Tarphius
   gabrielae sp. nov. (Pico) and Tarphius floresensis sp. nov. (Flores).
   Descriptions, photographs of holotypes and morphological details, and
   remarks on diagnostic features comparing similar species are presented.
   Additional information on the distribution and conservation status of
   the 12 described species in the archipelago is also provided.
C1 Borges, Paulo A.V.; cE3c, Azorean Biodivers Grp, Rua Capitao Joao dAvila
   S-N, Angra Do Heroismo, Acores, P-9700042, Portugal, Portugal.

RI Serrano, Artur Raposo Moniz/P-6425-2015; Borges, Paulo/H-5153-2019;
   Borges, Paulo/B-2780-2008; Amorim, Isabel R./AAW-2610-2020
OI Borges, Paulo/0000-0002-8448-7623; Borges, Paulo/0000-0002-8448-7623;

   Francois/0000-0001-6882-1591; Emerson, Brent/0000-0003-4067-9858

DT Article
TI Taxonomy of 'Euconnus complex'. Part XI. Status of Euconophron and
   Scopophus (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae, Scydmaeninae).
AU Jaloszynski, Pawel (scydmaenus@yahoo.com) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 4236
IS 3
PS 450-460
PD Feb 24 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Euconophron was described over a century ago and includes over 120
   nominal species, being the third largest subgenus of Euconnus. However,
   its diagnosis remains unclear. Western Palaearctic species seem to form
   a homogenous group characterized by emarginate or bifurcate aedeagal
   apex, whereas exotic members of this subgenus show a great diversity in
   external and genital characters. Moreover, Scopophus, a Nearctic
   subgenus of Euconnus, and at least some species placed in Euconnus s.
   str. outside Europe seem to be very similar to Euconophron. In the
   present paper the status of Euconophron and Scopophus is verified on the
   basis of morphological structures of their type species, i.e.,
   Scydmaenus promptus Coquerel (the type species of Euconophron) and
   Euconnus affinis Casey (the type species of Scopophus), each represented
   by respective type specimens. It is concluded that: i) the redescription
   of Scydmaenus promptus published by H. Franz was based on a
   misidentified specimen; ii) Euconophron can be maintained as a separate
   subgenus if unique characters of western Palaearctic species are
   included in its diagnosis; iii) Scopophus is a junior synonym of
   Euconnus s. str.; iv) status of species currently placed in Euconophron
   that occur outside western Palaearctic seems dubious, some of them may
   belong in Euconnus s. str. (this problem requires further study and
   species redescriptions); v) Euconnus s. str. and Euconophron may be
   closely related. Emended diagnosis of Euconophron is given, and
   lectotypes are designated for Scydmaenus promptus and Euconnus affinis.
C1 Jaloszynski, Pawel; Univ Wroclaw, Museum Nat Hist, Sienkiewicza 21,
   Wroclaw, PL-50335, Poland, Poland.
EM scydmaenus@yahoo.com
OI Jaloszynski, Pawel/0000-0003-2973-1803
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Type material; Diagnosis; Synonymy; Taxonomy
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Staphylinoidea,
   Scydmaenidae
OR Euconnus (Euconnus) - Thompson 1859 (Scydmaenidae): [Syn nov, Euconnus
   (Scopophus) Casey 1897, p. 459]. 
   Euconnus (Euconophron) - Reitter 1909 (Scydmaenidae): [Emended
   diagnosis, P. 453; Status, P. 452]. 
   Euconnus affinis - Casey 1897 (Scydmaenidae): [Lectotype designated, P.
   454]. 
   Scydmaenus promptus - Coquerel 1860 (Scydmaenidae): [Lectotype
   designated, P. 459].

DT Article
TI The taxonomic status of Long-tailed shrews (Mammalia: genus Sorex) from
   Nuclear Central America.
AU Matson, John O. (johnomatson@gmail.com) 
   Ordonez-Garza, Nicte
SO Zootaxa
VL 4236
IS 3
PS 461-483
PD Feb 24 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB We examined 256 specimens of long-tailed shrews (Sorex) from 53
   localities throughout the highlands of Nuclear Central America. We
   evaluate the efficacy of using three qualitative characteristics to
   identify populations of Sorex from Nuclear Central America: 1) the
   presence or the absence of a postmandibular foramen and canal; 2)
   relative size of U3 compared to U4; and, 3) the presence or absence of a
   pigmented ridge on the lingual side of each unicuspid tooth. In our
   data, the first character is invariable for the specimens we examined.
   Two species groups can be recognized based on the presence (S. salvini
   species group) or the absence of a postmandibular foramen and canal (S.
   veraepacis species group). The other two characteristics were useful,
   but not diagnostic. Based upon Principal Component Analysis we recognize
   nine species of Sorex in Nuclear Central America. Five species belong to
   the S. salvini species group: S. cristobalensis, S. salvini, S.
   sclateri, S. stizodon, and a new species from Honduras. Four species
   belong to the S. veraepacis species group: S. chiapensis, S. ibarrai, S.
   veraepacis, and a new species from western Guatemala. We also present
   evidence that the type locality (Coban, Alta Verapaz, Guatemala) for S.
   veraepacis is not correct.
C1 Matson, John O.; San Jose State Univ, Dept Biol Sci, San Jose, CA,
   95192, USA, USA.
EM johnomatson@gmail.com
OI Ordonez-Garza, Nicte/0000-0002-7732-7824
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Biometrics; Colour and
   luminescence; Skeletal and supporting structures; Skeleton; Land zones;
   Neotropical region; Central America
DE Sorex [Biometrics / Morphometrics / systematics] [Colour / Pelage colour
   / ] [Skull / Skull characters / ] [Central America / Nuclear Central
   America / distribution]. 
   Sorex madrensis [Guatemala /  / New species]. 
   Sorex mccarthyi [Honduras /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Insectivores; Mammals; Vertebrates

   Sorex madrensis (Soricidae): [Sp nov, Guatemala, P. 479]. 
   Sorex mccarthyi (Soricidae): [Sp nov, Honduras, P. 475]. 
   Sorex veraepacis - Alston 1877 (Soricidae): [Type locality, P. 473].
